children.subject: Data 8 might have been a waste of time but the other 4 classes won’t be.  My 4 “other” classes - Data 100, CS 189, EE126, CS 188.  It was either this or graduate in 2 years. By doing this, this allows me to take the majority of the CS 16x classes and still graduate in 2.5 years (if I wanted to, most likely it willl be 3).

While this is probably good advice, if you already have a CS degree, having a DS major is going to add little value in terms of career prospects. Taking 4 extra classes might not seem a big deal, but imo you're gonna be wasting time you could've spent on interesting research or cool side-projects.

Props to OP for writing out such a detailed and clear post. 

Just one piece of advice I'll give to anyone reading this (coming from a rising senior that's experienced a lot - classes/clubs/internships/TAing...), if you don't actually have a true passion for Data Science please don't double major in it for your resume. Nobody in the real world cares. If you're looking for a software engineering job, having a second major in data science is useless. If you want to go into data science, major in it. Not sure? Pick one and take the classes that you're interested in for both (if you happen to fulfill all the requirements, then fine double major). It is so much more important to have personal projects/do work for clubs/research/TA (not necessarily all of them!) for your career. You also only have the opportunity to go to college once. You should take classes that you're interested in (within your major department and outside of it!) rather than wasting your precious time to add a few words to your degree.

history.content:
There was a question posed recently on using DS as a fallback in case the CS 3.30 gauntlet isn't passed.  This is a fairly common thought, and it's a good fallback.  I would say that if you're going to go so far as to take Data 8, you might as well double-major in Data Science. Learning how to double-dip (taking one class to fulfill 2 requirements) saves you time and money, if that's a goal of yours. One reason why is that many of the Data Science classes can be used to double-dip into your 7 breadth classes and your American Cultures required class.  Not only that, 2 of the other classes can then overlap with CS classes.  So if you really really plan well, it's possible you have as little as 3 extra classes in addition to Data 8 -> Data 100 plus 2 other classes. So a total of 4 classes.  Seems like a very small sacrifice to get a double major.

Incremental DS classes:

LD - Data 8 + LD Domain emphasis

UD - Data 100

     2 CID classes (these can be your 2 CS overlap classes)

     Probability class

     MLDM class

     HCE class

     2 UD Domain Emphases classes

Remember, as a CS major, you've already got a freebie in that CS 61C satisfies a Physical Science breadth, so I'm not going to list any for Physical Science.

Data Science Upper Division requires you to take a Human Contexts and Ethics (HCE) class.  These are the classes where you can double dip (DS requirement + breadth):

AMERSTD 134 - Information Technology and Society - Social Sciences

BIOENG 100 - Ethics in Science and Engineering - Philosophy

ESPM C167 - Environmental Health and Development  - Biological or Social Sciences

HIST C184D - Human Contexts and Ethics of Data - Philosophy or Historical

PHILOS 121 - Moral Questions of Data Science - Philosophy

Then you need to take 3 classes to complete your Domain Emphasis (DE).  Here are some sample domain emphases combinations where you can take all 3 classes to fulfill 3 different breadths:

Cognition:

MCELL BI C61 - Brain, Mind and Behavior - Social Sciences

COGSCI C101 - Cognitive Linguistics - Philosophy

COGSCI C127 - Cognitive Neuroscience - Biological

Data Arts and Humanities:

ART 23AC - Data Arts - Arts&Literature AND American Cultures (triple-dipping)

INFO 103 - History of Information - Historical or Social Sciences

RHETOR 107 - Rhetoric of Scientific Discourse - Philosophy

Environment, Resource Management, and Society:

ESPM 50AC - (Historical or Philosophy or Social) AND American Cultures

ESPM155AC - Sociology and Political Ecology of Agro-Food Systems - Social AND American Cultures

ESPM 186 - Management and Conversation of Rangeland - Biological

Inequalities In Society:

SOCIOL 3AC - Principles of Sociology and American Cultures - Social AND American Cultures

AFRICAM 111 - Race, Class and Gender in the United States - Historical or Social

PUB POL C103 - Wealth and Poverty

Social Welfare, Health and Poverty:

SOCIOL 3AC - Principles of Sociology and American Cultures - Social AND American Cultures

GPP 105 - The Ethics, Methods, and Pragmatics of Global Practice - International or Philosophy or Social

ESPM C167 - Environmental Health and Development  - Biological or Social Sciences

Urban Science:

GEOG 70AC - The Urban Experience - (Historical or Social) AND American Cultures

CY PLAN 110 - Introduction to City Planning (Historical or Social)

ENV DES 100 - The City:  Theories and Methods in Urban Studies - International or Social

Now there are an endless amount of combinations you can take for your DE, and it's likely that one or two or maybe all 3 of your classes don't fall under any breadth.  I think your HCE combined with DE covers at least 2 breadths, you've done ok, 3 you've done fantastic, and all 4 - you are the ultimate planner (either that or you didn't give a $hit about what classes you took).
history.subject: Double majoring in Data Science - Double Dipping
